DOCNAME: CASE OF LINDNER AND HAMMERMAYER v. ROMANIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1;No violation of P1-1;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Inadmissible under P4-2-2
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants live in GPE , GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants ' mother acquired title to a property in GPE composed of CARDINAL flats . On DATE she sold CARDINAL of the flats to ORG In DATE she emigrated to GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG took possession of the property pursuant to LAW no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL . The applicants ' mother was never informed of the grounds or legal basis for that confiscation .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants , as heirs , brought proceedings against ORG and the managing company of ORG - owned housing , ORG , in ORG of the first district of GPE to have the confiscation order against the property set aside . They argued that their mother had been the owner of the property and that the ORG had confiscated it pursuant to LAW no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , but that the deprivation of property had been unlawful because the administrative confiscation order had never been served on their mother . On DATE the court delivered a judgement which was subsequently set aside by a decision of DATE of ORG following a procedural flaw . The case was then remitted to ORG .

CARDINAL . NORP In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE the court granted the claim on the ground that the administrative confiscation order in favour of the ORG had not satisfied the statutory formal conditions . Accordingly , it held that the ORG had not lawfully acquired title to the property and that the applicants were the lawful owners . The court ordered the confiscation order to be set aside and the property to be returned to the applicants .
CARDINAL . An appeal by ORG was dismissed on CARDINAL DATE by ORG on the same grounds as ORG .

CARDINAL . ORG appealed to ORG . In a judgment of DATE the court allowed the appeal and dismissed the applicants ' action for recovery of possession . It found that the property in question had become ORG property pursuant to a valid legal title , namely ORG decision of DATE , and held that in order to secure its return or , if applicable , compensation , the applicants ' only remedy was under the provisions of PERSON no . CARDINAL on the restitution of certain nationalised property .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG sold CARDINAL of the remaining CARDINAL flats to the former tenant .
CARDINAL . The relevant domestic legislation and case - law are set out in the GPE v. GPE judgment ( [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL , § § DATE , ECHR CARDINAL-VII ) .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL on the confiscation of certain real property read as follows :
“ In GPE of GPE title to real property , buildings and land can only vest in natural persons who are domiciled in the country . ”

“ Anyone who has applied for permission to leave the country with the intention of permanently settling abroad must first dispose of their real property in favour of the ORG and can do so up until the date of their departure ... . Real property belonging to persons who have illegally left the county or have failed to return within the statutory time - limit shall become the property of ORG with no compensation whatsoever . ... ”

CARDINAL . The position of ORG on this point can be summarised in the following way : on DATE the full ORG found that the courts did not have a common position on the subject of actions for recovery of possession by which applicants sought restitution , under the ordinary law , of real property confiscated under Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL . It noted that some courts had held that such actions were inadmissible on the ground that the claims should have been brought under the special law enacted for that purpose , Law no . QUANTITY , whereas others had held that they were admissible . ORG concluded that the courts did have jurisdiction to examine , under the ordinary law , actions for recovery of possession of property confiscated by the ORG pursuant to Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL .
